topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 1.1: Installation Prerequisites

body.p: This document describes the prerequisite steps and one time setup on your HLM host required to install HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade in a baremetal environment.

section.title: Hardware and software requirements
section.p: Before you start, if you have not done so already, make sure your environment meets the hardware and software requirements. See the HP Helion OpenStack Support Matrix.

section.title: Preparing the HLM host
section.p: Perform the following tasks on the HLM host:
section.title: Install Ubuntu Server 14.04.2 LTS
section.p: The HLM host must have Ubuntu Server 14.04.2 LTS installed before performing the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation.

section.title: Configure proxy information
section.p: Before you begin your installation on the HLM host, configure the proxy information for your environment using the following steps:

ol.li: Launch a terminal and log in to your HLM host as root:sudo su -

Edit the /etc/environment file to add the following lines, using values specific to your environment:PATH="/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games" export http_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export https_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,<HLM_host_IP_address>,<provider_network>
Where:<web_proxy_IP> is your web proxy IP address. <HLM_host_IP_address> is the IP address of the HLM Host
Source the environments file:source /etc/environment

section.title: Install Ubuntu packages
section.p: Before starting the installation, you must install the following packages on the KVM host.
To install the packages on the KVM host:

ol.li: On the KLM host, run the following all in one command to install packages: sudo su -l -c "apt-get install -y ansible sshpass ntp firefox gedit xrdp xfce4 qemu-kvm libvirt-bin openvswitch-switch openvswitch-common python-libvirt qemu-system-x86 libssl-dev libffi-dev git python-virtualenv python-dev virt-manager gnugpg jq"
Add the 802.1q module to the kernel on boot. The 802.1q standard supports VLAN tagging on an ethernet network.sudo su -c 'echo "8021q" >> /etc/modules'
Reboot the server
Log out and re-login to the HLM host to activate the proxy configuration.

section.title: Configure the XRDP remote desktop display
section.p: Configure XRDP on the KVM host for the remote desktop connection to access the server remotely as follows.

ol.li:
Edit the sesman.ini file: vi /etc/xrdp/sesman.ini
Update theMaxSessions=1 to MaxSessions=50.
Save and close the file.
Configure the system to use XRDP:echo "xfce4-session" > ~/.xinitrc
Restart the XDRP service: sudo /etc/init.d/xrdp restart

section.p: If the XDRP display does not work as expected, (you see a gray screen), update the startwm.sh file:

codeblock.codeph:
vi /etc/xrdp/startwm.sh
#!/bin/sh
if [ -r /etc/default/locale ]; then . /etc/default/locale export LANG LANGUAGE fi
#. /etc/X11/Xsession . /usr/bin/startxfce4

section.p: Make sure you add a space after "." then restart XDRP:

section.title: Install and configure NTP
section.p: You must configure the HLM Host as an NTP client.
You can install NTP on the HLM host and configure it as an NTP server. Or, you can use a pre-existing NTP server that is reachable from the management network.
For information on configuring the KLM host as an NTP client, see .
For information on installing NTP on the HLM host, see Installing an NTP Server.

section.title: Configure SSH
section.p: On the HLM host, the OpenSSH server must be running and the firewall configuration should allow access to the SSH ports.

ol.li: Enable root login in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config by setting the following values and save the file: # Authentication: LoginGraceTime 120 #PermitRootLogin without-password PermitRootLogin yes #StrictModes yes StrictModes no PermitRootLogin yes
Disable strict host key checking: in the ~/.ssh/config file (create the file if it does not exist) add following lines and save the file: Host * StrictHostKeyChecking no
Restart the SSH service:service ssh restart

Configure the public key and passwordless SSH access.
a. Enter the following command:ssh-keygen -t rsa
b. Press Enter to use default path (/root/.ssh/id_rsa)
c. Press Enter when prompted for the passphrase.
d. Press enter again to confirm the empty passphrase.
The output of the public key will display, similar to the following:ssh-copy-id 192.168.122.1
If you get a permission denied error, make sure you are logged in as root.

section.title: Preparing the Network for Installation
section.p: Before installing HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade, you are responsible for preparing the network for all installations.
See Preparing the Network for Installation

section.title: Download and unpack the installation packages
section.p: Before you begin, you must download the required HP Helion OpenStack installation package(s).
Note: When downloading installation files, always download and verify the signature file before installing.

ol.li:
In a browser, navigate to Helion Download Network(HDN).
Click Sign In to log in using your account.
After signing in, click the Downloads link in the menu on the left side of the page.
On the Downloads page, locate HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade and click Download.

Download the following files:
Helion Carrier Grade 1.1.0. The file is named hcg_1.1.0.tar. Also download the Checksum and Signature files.
Horizon Patch Tar File for Helion Carrier Grade. The file is named hcg_1.1.0_horizon_patch1.tar. Also download the Checksum and Signature files.
GPG keys to verify signature files. This file is named GPG-HPCSS-Public-Keys.tar.
vCenter Proxy Appliance. For the KVM + ESX deployment, download this file, named overcloud_vcenter_compute_proxy.tar. Also download the Signature files.
Extract the hcg_1.1.0.tar file to the images folder: /var/lib/libvirt/images.
Copy the cg-infra-playbooks.tar.gz.gpg file from the hcg_1.1.0.tar files to the /root directory.
Extract the GPG-HPCSS-Public-Keys.tar file using the password cghelion when prompted. gpg -d cg-infra-playbooks.tar.gz.gpg | tar -xzvf
Create the /root/cg/ directory
Copy the cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg file from the hcg_1.1.0.tar files to the /root/cg/ directory.

Unzip the DCN packages:

section.title: Verify the download signature
section.p: After downloading the installation packages, you should verify the signature of the download. You can use the GPG utility, which is already installed on the HLM node. Signed by the signature file.
A set of GPG public keys are included in the installation package you downloaded.

ol.li:
Copy the public keys to the HLM host server, extract the keys from the compressed files.
The following keys are included in the download:
Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA(HPCodesigningService)-1.pub
Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA(HPCodesigningService)-2.pub
Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA(HPCodesigningService)-3.pub
Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA(HPCodesigningService)-4.pub
Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA(HPCodesigningService)-5.pub
hpPublicKey.pub
hpPublicKey2048.pub

Execute the following command to import the keys: gpg --import "<filename>"
Where <filename> is the name of the extracted file.
The keys are then imported into the gpgp key share: gpg --import hpPublicKey.pub gpg --import Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA\(HPCodesigningService\)-1.pub gpg --import Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA\(HPCodesigningService\)-2.pub gpg --import Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA\(HPCodesigningService\)-3.pub gpg --import Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA\(HPCodesigningService\)-4.pub gpg --import Hewlett-PackardCompanyRSA\(HPCodesigningService\)-5.pub gpg --import hpPublicKey2048.pub

Use the following command to view the keys in the key store: gpg --list-keys
The key store appears similar to the following:/home/sad/.gnupg/pubring.gpg ---------------------------- pub 2048R/F7191CB9 2014-12-19 pub 1024D/2689B887 2005-03-11 [expired: 2015-03-09] uid Hewlett-Packard Company (HP Codesigning Service) pub 2048R/B1275EA3 2014-11-19 [expires: 2024-11-16] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 1 pub 2048R/B564A643 2014-11-19 [expires: 2024-11-16] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 2 pub 2048R/FF94BC78 2014-11-19 [expires: 2024-11-16] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 3 pub 2048R/BA849975 2014-11-19 [expires: 2024-11-16] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 4 pub 2048R/C6978F0C 2014-11-19 [expires: 2024-11-16] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 5 pub 2048R/5CE2D476 2012-12-04 [expires: 2022-12-02] uid Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service)

Use the following command to verify the signature: gpg --verify ./cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg.sig ./cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg
The output for the command appears similar to the following. This indicates the signature is verified: Good signature from "Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service).gpg: Signature made Wed 22 Jul 2015 01:23:24 PM EDT using RSA key ID C6978F0C gpg: Good signature from "Hewlett-Packard Company RSA (HP Codesigning Service) - 5" gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature! gpg: There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner. Primary key fingerprint: 2545 62E5 28F9 FE92 B85D 8200 FDF9 4EBB C697 8F0C

section.title: Verify the download checksums
section.p:
You should also use a checksum verification tool, such as sha256sum, which should come installed with Ubuntu.
Run the checksum tool against the hcg_1.1.0.tar file. sha256sum <path-to-file>hcg_1.1.0.tar
Compare the output of the checksum tool to the hcg_1.1.0.tar.sha256 file. sha256sum.exe hcg_1.1.0.tar 97f5b83c7aa0410ecc90f870f22bf8a691f8491a69c2ec26e0e71a24 hcg_1.1.0.tar Note that the chechsum file contains the date that the file was generated, the checksum string, and the name of the file that was used:Fri Jul 31 10:55:37 EDT 2015 97f5b83c7aa0410ecc90f870f22bf8a691f8491a69c2ec26e0e71a24 hcg_1.1.0.tar
Run the checksum tool against the hcg_1.1.0_horizon_patch1.tar file. sha256sum <path-to-file>hcg_1.1.0_horizon_patch1.tar
Compare the output of the checksum tool to the hcg_1.1.0.tar.sha256 file. sha256sum.exe hcg_1.1.0.tar 97f5b83c7aa0410ecc90f870f22bf8a691f8491a69c2ec26e0e71a24 hcg_1.1.0.tar

section.title: Preparing the baremetal systems
section.p: Perform the following tasks on each server you will use as a compute server or controller in the non-KVM and KVM regions:

ul.li:
Configure the boot order with Network/PXE boot as the first option:
For example, to set the boot order for a HP SL390, from the iLO prompt enter set system1/bootconfig1/bootsource5 bootorder=1.
to the correct date and time
with only one network interface enabled for PXE/network boot and any additional interfaces should have PXE/network boot disabled
to stay powered off in the event of being shutdown rather than automatically restarting

li.p: Update to the latest firmware recommended by the system vendor for all system components, including the BIOS, BMC firmware, disk controller firmware, drive firmware, network adapter firmware, and so forth.
Note: If you are using ProLiant Gen9 blades or rack servers, you must update the Snap3 firmware.
